awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Physiological mechanisms involved in the allocation of energy to reproduction in corals under thermal stress
awd_abstract_narration:
Coral reefs are diverse tropical ecosystems that provide storm protection and support economic livelihoods for fishing and tourism in coastal communities.  The long-term health of reefs worldwide is being negatively impacted by increased seawater temperatures that have led to coral bleaching and widespread coral mortality, especially during the last three years.  The goal of this research is to identify characteristics and physiological strategies that lead to successful coral reproduction and long-term recovery despite bleaching.  This information can be applied to coral conservation and management efforts.  Furthermore, these findings will be incorporated into community outreach activities, as follows: in Hawaii, to develop a workshop with elementary teachers from Hawaiian immersion schools; in Washington, with Seattle MESA (Mathematics Engineering Science and Achievement for underrepresented minorities, women, at-risk and economically disadvantaged youth) to connect science fundamentals to the real world and work with teachers to develop marine biology lesson plans; and in Pennsylvania, with the School District of Philadelphia to develop hands-on classroom activities and lead field trips to the local ocean with underserved high schools populated by over 90% minority students.

Most prior coral bleaching studies have focused on the potential of adult colonies to recover and acclimatize from stress. However, future reefs will not only require the survival of adults, but will also be dependent upon the continuation of sexual reproduction despite thermal stress. Little is known about the mechanisms corals use to tolerate and successfully reproduce in stressful environments. This interdisciplinary study will characterize the physiological and phenotypic responses associated with thermal stress and quantify the impacts of coral nutrition to reproduction.  The research will focus on an important and dominant reef builder in Hawaii that has the capacity to sexually reproduce despite bleaching. The objectives are to: (1) independently track the contribution of carbon and nitrogen acquired from parental photosynthesis and heterotrophy to gamete development in bleached and unbleached colonies; (2) develop nutritional proteome profiles of bleached and unbleached parental colonies and their eggs that have relied on different trophic sources throughout gamete development; and (3) use the proteomic surveys to develop a biomarker assay for coral trophic status. The findings of this study will detect biomarkers that can serve to monitor trophic status and identify coral species that are likely to recover and reproduce after a bleaching event. Altogether these data can be applied to conservation and management efforts and the development of accurate forecasting models.

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: VILLANOVA UNIVERSITY IN THE STATE OF PENNSYLVANIA

por.por_cntn:
Coral reefs are one of the most diverse ecosystems in the world. However, they are threatened by numerous stressors, including elevated ocean temperatures that often cause coral bleaching. Corals lose their ability to gain nutrients and some species die as a result, while others recover. The negative impacts on the health of adult coral colonies and the conditions that lead to recovery following bleaching are well understood. However, there is limited knowledge of how coral reproduction is affected by coral bleaching or the mechanisms involved that may lead to continued reproduction despite bleaching. The success of future coral reefs requires both adult recovery and the production of coral offspring even as ocean temperatures continue to warm. The goal of our study was to detect and trace molecules responsible for continued successful reproduction in the Hawaiian rice coral (Montipora capitata) that can reproduce even when bleached. With extensive field experiments conducted in Hawaii and laboratory approaches we attained the following objectives: (1) at the University of Washington we studied biomarker proteins in corals to identify those that contribute to recovery from bleaching; and (2) at Villanova University we followed nutritional pathways of carbon and nitrogen from adult colonies to gametes to identify the components corals use to develop eggs when bleached or non-bleached.

At Villanova University we traced carbon and nitrogen in bleached and non-bleached corals following coral photosynthesis and coral feeding. We found that in the months following bleaching, carbon was primarily obtained by adults from photosynthesis; this same carbon was incorporated into gametes released during spawning events. Nitrogen was obtained by adults from both photosynthesis and coral feeding; similarly, these same nitrogen atoms were transferred to gametes. For the first time we show direct transfer of nutrients from adults to offspring in corals that were previously bleached and those that were non-bleached. Our study identified nitrogen availability as an important mechanism of recovery from bleaching by adult coral hosts, their symbiotic algae, and continued successful gamete development. This study has been submitted and is being reviewed for publication in Frontiers in Ecology and Evolution. A companion comparative study of the finger coral (Porites compressa) found that the species recovered its carbon supply for adult coral hosts first, before providing carbon to gametes. M. capitata allocated 10% more carbon to gametes despite bleaching. Therefore, there may be several strategies used by corals to cope with bleaching and subsequent reproduction. This study is published in Scientific Reports. Altogether this research, along with the biomarker protein analyses conducted at the University of Washington, will help coral conservation and management efforts by improving our capacity to predict the response of coral reefs to future bleaching events.

Our study included a multi-tiered outreach approach that occurred in Hawaii, Washington, and Pennsylvania. In the Philadelphia, PA region, we partnered with several middle and high school student groups from predominantly low income and/or minoritized populations that are underrepresented in STEM disciplines: two high schools in Philadelphia, a Saturday program for high school students in Philadelphia, and an afterschool program for middle and high school student in Norristown, PA. Prior to the COVID-19 pandemic we developed a program called ?Getting Our Feet Wet? that included (1) a classroom visit for students to learn about oceans and corals reefs, (2) a field trip to the beach at Brigantine, NJ to conduct scientific activities along the coast, and (3) a campus visit to Villanova University for laboratory activities, lunch in the cafeteria, and a presentation by CASA, Villanova?s Center for the Access, Success and Achievement. During the lockdown, we transitioned to monthly presentations on oceans with a group of middle school girls from the afterschool program in Norristown. Their parents and siblings often attended the series of four discussions on the ocean environments and threats to oceans. Since returning to in-person operations, we have led waste audits for the program in Norristown, helped implement a classroom recycling center, and led a field trip to a local aquarium for fifty students for them to observe marine organisms.
